question: Please describe in no more than 200 words the following:
llm_answer:
The MitoComplexesLUHMES (MCL) assay is an in vitro method developed to assess compound‐induced impairments in mitochondrial complex activity (cI, cII, cIII, cIV) in human dopaminergic LUHMES cells. It involves seeding proliferative LUHMES cells on coated Seahorse XFe24 plates and allowing them to adhere and grow, before replacing the culture medium with a MAS buffer enriched with ADP and digitonin to permeabilize the cells. Using the Seahorse XF Analyzer, the assay measures the oxygen consumption rate (OCR) prior to and after the sequential injection of selective substrates and inhibitors. A two‐tiered screening approach is employed: tier 1 assesses cI (using pyruvate, glutamine, malate, and a cII inhibitor) and cIII (using duroquinol and a cI inhibitor), while tier 2 evaluates cII (using succinate and a cI inhibitor) and cIV (using TMPD, L-ascorbic acid, and a cII inhibitor). The assay provides mechanistic insights into mitochondrial disturbances that may underlie neurotoxicity, with careful internal and external quality controls ensuring reliability.  
_(Source: MitoComplexesLUHMESassay(MCL).pdf)_

In the MCL assay no full differentiation protocol is applied because the test system is based on LUHMES cells maintained in their proliferative (precursor) stage. Although LUHMES cells have the capacity to differentiate into mature dopaminergic neurons through a well‐established protocol (by exposure to tetracycline, GDNF, and db‐cAMP for approximately 6 days), this is not performed here. Instead, the following procedure is used:

1. Cells are derived from a master stock and propagated as working stocks. They are first expanded in proliferation medium—Advanced DMEM/F12 supplemented with 2 mM L‑glutamine, N2, and 40 ng/ml FGF—and cultured with regular medium changes (see Section 3.1 and 3.7).  
2. Culture vessels (plates or flasks) are pre‐coated with a solution of poly‑L‑ornithine (43 µg/ml) and fibronectin (1 µg/ml). This ensures even cell distribution and proper attachment.  
3. For the assay, proliferating LUHMES cells are trypsinized and re‑seeded into pre‑coated Agilent Seahorse XFe24-well plates in 100 µl of the proliferation medium. Raw data processing in our lab follows several well‐defined steps. First, the Seahorse XF Analyzer records oxygen levels (and pH) to calculate readouts such as the oxygen consumption rate (OCR). Next, artefacts and technical outliers are identified and excluded from the dataset (Source: Section 7.2). For normalization, the processing entails:
• Exporting the Seahorse XF Analyzer data (OCR values and corresponding metadata) into Excel.
• Normalizing each OCR measurement by dividing the first value recorded after the selective substrate feeding by the average of the corresponding untreated (solvent control; 0.1% DMSO) wells. In this way, the complex’s activity is expressed as a percentage relative to the control (Source: Section 7.3).

Once the normalized data are obtained, curve fitting is performed using Excel and GraphPad Prism to construct dose–response curves (e.g., fitting with a 4‑parameter logistic equation). Nonlinear regression is used to calculate parameters such as EC50. If a nonlinear fit is not possible, a linear curve is fitted. Additionally, benchmark concentration (BMC) values, together with their upper (BMCU) and lower (BMCL) confidence intervals, are computed using the online BMCeasy software (Source: Section 7.4).

Thus, the complete workflow is as follows:
1. Data collection by the Seahorse XF Analyzer with embedded metadata.
2. Exclusion of artefacts/outliers and background correction by normalizing to the last pre-injection measurement.
3. Exporting data into Excel, then normalizing the post-injection OCR values to the average of untreated controls (expressing complex activity in % of control).
4. Curve fitting using GraphPad Prism (or Excel) to derive dose–response parameters such as EC50 and further derivation of BMC values via BMCeasy.

Below is a summary of the prediction model and its thresholds as described in the EFSA NAMs case study document for the MCL assay (Sources: MitoComplexesLUHMESassay(MCL).pdf – Sections 8.2 and 8.3):

1. For dichotomized data:
 • The model considers a mitochondrial complex “inhibited” if its measured activity (normalized to baseline) decreases by more than 2× the standard deviation (2×SD) of the baseline variation. For complex I, an increase (i.e. uncoupling) beyond 2×SD is also noted.
 • In a dichotomized outcome, if the effect is beyond the ±2×SD threshold the result is labeled toxic (or indicative of an effect on that complex); if the effect remains within 2×SD of the baseline then the result is considered not toxic.

2. For pseudo-dichotomized outcomes (with a borderline class):
 • The borderline range can be defined as the range of responses that do not exceed the ±2×SD threshold. In other words, any change within ±2×SD of the baseline is regarded as borderline (or normal variation), whereas changes beyond this range are classified as clearly “toxic” (or indicative of complex inhibition/uncoupling).

3. For multi‑class or continuous outcomes:
 • The response is expressed as a percentage of the control (basal OCR normalized to the last measurement prior to compound injection).
 • The threshold is mathematically defined: a change exceeding 2×SD from the baseline (either as inhibition or as hyperactivity in the case of cI uncoupling) is considered clearly significant.
 • Rationale: A 2×SD threshold is used because it represents a statistically significant deviation from the baseline variation, meaning that any effect beyond this cut‐off is unlikely to be due to inherent measurement noise. This approach is based on an objective, mathematical criterion. Biologically, a marked change in the function of mitochondrial complexes (reflected as >2×SD deviation) is likely to alter cellular metabolism and is therefore of toxicological relevance.

Additional points on toxicological rationale, limitations, and screening hit definition:
 • Toxicological Rationale: Although the threshold is based on a mathematical criterion (2×SD), it also has biological meaning because the mitochondrial complexes are critical in maintaining cellular energy metabolism. A significant deviation suggests a functional impairment that can be linked to adverse outcomes.
 • Limitations: The model is reliant on the baseline variation being stable and representative. In cases where the baseline variability is high (or fluctuates due to technical or biological reasons), the 2×SD threshold may miss subtle yet biologically relevant changes or conversely flag minor deviations as toxic effects. Moreover, the assay only evaluates mitochondrial complex activity and may not capture other aspects of mitochondrial or cellular toxicity.
 • Screening (Hit) Definition: In screening mode, a “hit” is defined as any compound that causes a change in the measured activity of any of the four mitochondrial complexes (or uncoupling in the case of cI) beyond the 2×SD threshold compared to controls. This means that any compound producing a statistically significant deviation from the baseline (per the described criteria) will be flagged as a potential toxicant needing further evaluation.

This summary is based entirely on the information provided in the MitoComplexesLUHMESassay(MCL).pdf document (Sources: Sections 8.2 and 8.3).

The assay is designed to be one element in a broader neurotoxicity battery. It fills a gap by providing a mechanistic read‐out of mitochondrial complex inhibition (for complexes I–IV) that is not captured by assays focusing only on viability or neurite integrity. In a battery it can serve as a confirmation/ mechanistic follow‐up test to “de‐risk” alerts from screening assays and help clarify the mode of action (e.g. whether a compound impairs mitochondrial function via a specific complex). 

Key points include:  
• It brings mechanistic information (by distinguishing between inhibition of individual mitochondrial complexes) that supplements outcomes from related assays (such as neurite outgrowth or general mitochondrial stress assays).  
• Its internal controls allow the exclusion of artefacts (for example, verifying that oxygen consumption rate [OCR] does not change in negative controls), which is a strength compared to less precise or non‐mechanistic tests.  
• However, because it requires specialized instrumentation (a Seahorse XF Analyzer) and well‐trained operators, the throughput is lower than simpler screening assays; furthermore, the method has not been formally validated in multi‐lab ring trials yet.  
• Thus, in a potential test battery the method is best employed as a tier‐2 tool to follow up screening alerts—either as a stand‐alone mechanistic assessment for mitochondrial perturbation or as a complementary assay together with others (for example, assays for neurite integrity or viability).  

In summary, the assay fits into a neurotoxicity test battery by addressing mitochondrial dysfunction as a key event (for example, the AOP linking mitochondrial complex I inhibition to parkinsonian deficits). Its strengths (mechanistic clarity, built‐in controls) make it highly suitable for confirmation or mechanistic follow‑up, while its technical demands and specialization suggest it should not be used as a first‐tier screening assay by itself. Complementary assays (for endpoints such as neurite outgrowth, general viability, etc.) remain necessary as part of an integrated battery.
